am.pdf pdf false 2567968 AAM-PDF MCAT 114539 114539 S2468-8231(24)00721-1 10.1016/j.mcat.2024.114539 Fig. 1 (a) Typical routes in the HDO of phenol; (b) Reaction pathways in HDO of guaiacol; (c) The pathway of vanillin HDO. Fig 1 Fig. 2 (a) Mechanism of HDO of phenol over Ni2P@C and Ni@C catalysts [18]; (b) Main pathways in the pyrolysis and HDO process of guaiacol over Pd/NC catalysts [25]; (c) HDO reaction route of vanillin over Pd/CNS(1) catalyst [27]. Fig 2 Fig. 3 (a) Preparation diagram of Ru@NC-T catalyst; (b) SEM and (c and d) TEM image of Ru@NC-800; (e) HRTEM image; (f) HAADF-STEM image and (g) the corresponding EDX mapping images of Ru@NC-800 [39]. Fig 3 Fig. 4 (a) Schematic illustration of the process for the preparation of Ni2P@C(x) [18]. (b) The main preparation process of Ni@C and Ni2P@C-x catalyst [40]. (c) Schematic illustration of the preparation process of B, N-DHCM [41]. Fig 4 Fig. 5 (a) Synthesis of Pd/HCAFR-X; (b) Raman spectra of Pd/HCAFR-X series catalysts; (c) Pathway of reactant and product contents in Aph HDO with reaction time under the Pd/HCAFR-0.6; (d)Recycling tests for Aph HDO [54]; (e) NH3-TPD profiles of catalysts; (f) CoNx@NC cycle-catalysed eugenol HDO yield distribution [52]; (g) Turnover frequency values of Ni/AC and Ni/ACN-0.5 [53]. Carbon-based catalysts for hydrodeoxygenation of biomass derivatives: A review of heteroatom doping strategies Zihang Wang Writing – original draft Software Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Conceptualization a b Zhiyu Li Visualization Supervision Resources Investigation Data curation a b ⁎ Yuchun Zhang Supervision Resources Conceptualization a b Peng Fu Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources Funding acquisition Conceptualization a b ⁎ a College of Agricultural Engineering and Food Science, Shandong University of Technology, Zibo, China College of Agricultural Engineering and Food Science Shandong University of Technology Zibo China aCollege of Agricultural Engineering and Food Science, Shandong University of Technology, Zibo, China b Branch of State Key Laboratory of Woody Oil Resources Utilization at Shandong University of Technology, Zibo, China Branch of State Key Laboratory of Woody Oil Resources Utilization at Shandong University of Technology Zibo China bBranch of State Key Laboratory of Woody Oil Resources Utilization at Shandong University of Technology, Zibo, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of biomass derivatives is a critical method for converting these resources into fuels and chemicals. Carbon-based catalysts play a crucial role in HDO. In this review, the main advances and problems of heteroatom-doped carbon-based catalysts for the HDO of biomass derivatives, both domestically and internationally, in recent years are summarized. Herein, the review first summarizes the reaction mechanisms of HDO of typical model compounds. From the perspective of preparation methods of carbon-based catalysts, the advantages and shortcomings of in-situ doping and post-processing doping strategies are compared. The current research status of carbon-based catalysts is reviewed in terms of single-atom doping (N, P, B, and S) and atom co-doping (N-B, N-S, N-P, and NO), highlighting that heteroatom doping can introduce more acid-base sites on carbon-based materials, enhance their hydrophilicity, chemical stability, and conductivity. Additionally, anchor sites for metal nanoparticles can be provided to enhance their dispersion and stability, altering the electron distribution and charge density of the carbon-based catalysts, thus significantly improving catalytic efficiency and product selectivity. Finally, the review addresses current challenges and future research directions, emphasizing the need for rational catalyst design and a deeper understanding of the reaction mechanism to enhance biomass resource utilization. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Biomass Hydrodeoxygenation Carbon materials Heteroatoms Mechanisms Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The role of biomass energy as a renewable energy source in the global energy mix has been increasingly emphasized [1]. When compared to fossil fuels, biomass energy offers high sustainability, low carbon emissions, and diverse sources [2]. Sources of biomass include forest residues, agricultural wastes, and urban organic wastes. Effective utilization of these resources not only reduces environmental pollution but also enhances energy use efficiency [3,4]. Catalytic hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is an effective method for converting biomass derivatives into high-value chemicals or fuels, making the development of new and efficient HDO catalysts particularly critical [5]. Carbon-based catalysts exhibit significant advantages for biomass HDO, primarily due to their ability to promote the formation of small particles, high dispersion, and uniform distribution of metal active phases, thus increasing the exposure of active sites and enhancing catalytic activity [6,7]. Additionally, the mesoporous structure and abundant specific surface area of carbon materials reduce diffusion limitations and enhance the contact between reactants and active metal phases, further improving catalytic efficiency [8,9]. Introducing heteroatoms such as O, N, and P adjusts the hydrophilicity and acid-base properties of the carbon carriers to optimize the dispersion of the metal active phase and enhance the interaction between the catalyst surface and reactants in polar solvents [10]. The electrical conductivity and surface functional groups of carbon materials affect electron transfer, regulating the reaction path and catalytic performance of biomass HDO [11]. Selective cleavage of specific bonds in the HDO reaction can be achieved by rationally designing the active sites and surface structures of catalysts, thereby regulating product formation [12]. Moreover, well-stabilised catalysts can remain active over extended periods, reducing catalyst deactivation and regeneration cycles during the reaction process, which lowers costs and improves reaction continuity [13,14]. This paper reviews the preparation methods of different non-metallic atom-doped carbon-based catalysts, summarizes the current research status of carbon-based catalysts for the HDO of biomass derivatives, focusing on single-atom doping (N, P, B, and S) and co-doping (N-B, N-S, N-P, and NO). It discusses the mechanism by which heteroatom-doped carbon-based catalysts catalyse the HDO of biomass derivatives and provides a perspective on future catalyst development, highlighting its significance for promoting sustainable energy development and offering a reference for the subsequent application of carbon-based catalysts in the HDO of biomass derivatives to produce fuels or chemicals. 2 Hydrodeoxygenation reaction mechanism HDO is considered to be one of the most effective and feasible strategies for biomass upgrading, which achieves the removal of oxygen functional groups from bio-oil oxygenated compounds by cleaving the CO-C, CO-H, and CC bonds in the biomass and its derivatives, thus enhancing their stability and energy density to obtain high-value chemicals and alternative fuels. In the process of hydrodeoxygenation, there may be multiple reaction types, such as hydrogenation, hydrogenolysis, dehydration, alkyl transfer, etc., with cumbersome pathways and complex mechanisms, so researchers have mostly used model compounds with relatively simple structures as the research objects to explore the reaction mechanisms and screen efficient catalysts to realize the targeted control of a single reaction type and obtain higher selectivity of target products. Phenol, as a relatively simple model compound, is often used as a substrate to study the mechanism of direct CO bond cleavage. Using phenol as an example, during the HDO reaction on heteroatom-doped carbon-based catalysts, three main pathways might exist, as illustrated in Fig. 1a [15-17]: (1) Hydrodeoxygenation pathway. The aromatic ring of phenol is partially hydrogenated and undergoes isomerization to form the primary product cyclohexanone, which is then further hydrogenated to produce cyclohexanol. The generation of cyclohexanol from phenol by tandem hydrogenation is a fast process and the product is difficult to stay at the cyclohexanone stage. Cyclohexanol can undergo a dehydration reaction (CO bond cleavage), which is the rate-determining step of the process. Once formed, cyclohexene is rapidly hydrogenated to produce the final product cyclohexane. (2) Direct Deoxygenation Path. This reaction path appears on the surface to be a direct deoxygenation, where the phenolic hydroxyl group of phenol is hydrogenated to form benzene, while breaking the CO bond and consuming an equimolar amount of hydrogen, making this path more atomically economical. However, compared to cyclohexanol, phenol has a higher CO bond energy and direct dehydroxylation is relatively difficult. (3) Isomerization pathway. In this mechanism, phenol first undergoes isomerization to produce an enone intermediate (2,4-cyclohexadienone), which then undergoes a different functional group hydrogenation path. When the C = C double bond of the intermediate undergoes hydrogenation, cyclohexanone is produced, followed by hydrodeoxygenation, following the same course as in (a); when the carbonyl group of the enone intermediate undergoes hydrogenation, alcohol is produced, which is further dehydrated to produce benzene, following the isomerization-deoxygenation route. In the hydrodeoxygenation reaction, both the reaction path and reaction type are closely related to the adsorption and desorption behaviors of reactants and intermediates at the active site. Wang et al. [18] prepared a carbon-coated Ni2P catalyst (Ni2P@C) and applied it to the phenol HDO reaction. As shown in Fig. 2a , on the one hand, benzene is produced from phenol via direct deoxygenation (DDO) by breaking the CO bond. On the other hand, cyclohexanol is formed through the hydrogenation of the aromatic ring, primarily via the HYD pathway, followed by the dehydration of cyclohexanol to cyclohexene, which is ultimately hydrogenated to yield cyclohexane. Guaiacol is the most widely studied model compound of choice for extraction from bio-oils. In HDO of biomass derivatives and bio-oils, the critical step is the cleavage of the CO bond. Guaiacol molecules have three types of CO bonds: COCH3, C–OCH3, and COH [19,20]. Among these, the CO bond in COCH3 is readily cleaved by demethylation [21]. Consequently, guaiacol is generally demethylated to form catechol, which is then cleaved from the CO bond attached to the hydroxyl group to give phenol, as shown in Fig. 1b. Secondary reaction pathways include direct demethoxylation or initial dehydroxylation followed by demethylation to produce phenol. Furthermore, with increasing reaction temperature and H2 pressure, hydrogenation of the aromatic ring is inevitable and often occurs more readily than hydrogenation of the CO bond [22]. After guaiacol is converted to phenol via HDO, further hydrogenation of the aromatic ring can lead to the formation of products such as cyclohexanol, cyclohexene, and cyclohexane. Another reaction pathway involves the initial hydrogenation of the aromatic ring to form 2-methoxycyclohexanol, followed by dehydroxylation and demethoxylation to yield cyclohexane [23,24]. Liu et al. [25] investigated nitrogen-doped carbon-loaded palladium catalyst (Pd/NC) for the HDO reaction of guaiacol. On the Pd/C catalyst, guaiacol was mainly converted to catechol and methane through homolytic cleavage, i.e., homolytic cleavage of the CH3 O bond, and then to phenol, and the deoxygenation reaction was promoted by the reactive hydrogen atoms generated by the dissociation of hydrogen molecules on the Pd surface. However, on the Pd/NC catalyst, the methoxy group (–OCH3) of guaiacol prefers to form phenol via a reaction path that eliminates hydrogen atoms, followed by the possible fracture of the methylene group (OCH2) via a hydrogen-attract reaction. Phenol as a key intermediate was efficiently converted to deoxygenated products over Pd/NC catalysts, a process that benefited from the stabilizing effect of the nitrogen-doped carbon carriers on the Pd particles and the modulation of the electronic states, as shown in Fig. 2b. Tan et al. [26] reported the reaction pathway for the HDO of guaiacol over the nitrogen-doped carbon-based catalyst FeCoNi@NC, which firstly undergoes demethylation and hydrolysis to catechol, followed by hydrolysis to phenol in the presence of formic acid.The increase in electron density on the NC shell layer improves the adsorption strength of the reactants and intermediates, thereby lowering the energy barrier for formic acid dehydrogenation and guaiacol HDO. Vanillin is a model biomass phenolic compound derived from lignin. Vanillin contains three main functional groups including carbonyl, hydroxyl and ether bonds, and the HDO mechanism is shown in Fig. 1c [28]. Vanillin HDO usually involves the hydrogenation of the C = O double bond on the aldehyde group of vanillin to 4-hydroxymethyl-2-methoxyphenol, which is then hydrolyzed to 2‑methoxy-4-methylphenol. The 2‑methoxy-4-methylcatechol is then demethoxylated to produce 4-methylphenol, which is more susceptible to aromatic ring saturation to obtain cycloalkane compounds. Similar to guaiacol, 4-methylphenol tended to undergo cyclohydrogenation to methylcyclohexanol with increasing temperature and hydrogen pressure. Finally, the methylcyclohexanol is dehydroxylated and hydrogenated to give the final product, methylcyclohexane[29,30]. However, due to the large spatial site resistance of the three oxygen-containing functional groups, the reaction temperature for the complete deoxygenation of vanillin by HDO usually needs to be higher than 300 °C[31]. Therefore, at lower temperatures, 2‑methoxy-4-methylphenol is the major product. Kuang et al. [27] investigated the HDO reaction mechanism of vanillin over a Pd/CNS(1) catalyst as shown in Fig. 2c, which involves hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis reactions, with the formation of Pd(0) nanoparticles in the electron-rich region of the carbon carrier, which catalyses the silica-hydrogen addition reaction of PMHS and releases the proton donor while the carbon defective surface promotes substrate adsorption and activation. The Pd0 nanoparticles hydrogenate vanillin to vanillyl alcohol, which is followed by the breaking of the CO bond, generating the methyl cations, and ultimately, forming the target product 2‑methoxy- 4-methylphenol. 3 Synthetic strategies for heteroatom-doped carbon-based catalysts Two strategies are routinely used to prepare heteroatom-doped carbon-based catalysts: (1) Post-processing doping involves initially synthesizing carbon materials and subsequently modifying them via chemical or thermal treatment using reagents containing heteroatoms (e.g., NH3, urea, melamine, H2S, phosphoric acid, sulfur, sodium sulfate, poly-Rhodamine, cysteine, etc.) [32,33]. (2) In-situ doping involves concurrent heteroatom doping during carbon materials synthesis, often employing methods such as the template method, chemical vapor deposition (CVD) [34], and pyrolysis . Additionally, Metal-Organic Frameworks (MOFs) serve as excellent precursors for synthesizing heteroatom-doped carbon-based catalysts [35,36]. 3.1 In-situ doping In-situ doping involves directly introducing doping elements during the synthesis of carbon-based catalysts, such as adding a nitrogen source (e.g., ammonia, urea, etc.) to the carbon precursor material during the synthesis of nitrogen-doped carbon materials. Since the doping process occurs simultaneously with carbon material synthesis, it enables a highly uniform doping effect. In situ doping allows for the early introduction of doping elements in catalyst synthesis, facilitating full interaction with the doping element throughout the process, leading to enhanced catalytic stability[37]. However, this method has disadvantages such as a complicated preparation process, high cost, and demanding selection of precursors and synthesis conditions. MOF-derived heteroatom-doped synthetic routes show great potential due to the high structural/chemical tunability, abundant specific surface area, and high porosity of MOFs. Dou et al. [38] prepared hollow nitrogen-doped carbon-cage-constrained Cu-Co alloy catalysts by a one-pot method using ZIF-67 as a template. The results showed that the alloying of Co with Cu improved the activity and selectivity of the catalyst. The CuCo/NC-2 catalyst showed 100 % furan aldehydes (FAL) conversion and 95.7 % 2-methylfuran (2-MF) yield under relatively mild reaction conditions. The introduction of Cu shifted the optimal adsorption model of substrate molecules, promoted the dissociation of H2, the breakage of CO bonds, and lowered the diffusion barrier of H, thus facilitated the formation of 2-MF, and successfully hindered the excessive hydrogenation of the furan ring. Wang et al. [18] used Ni-MOF-74 as a template for pyrolysis and phosphorylation reactions under a nitrogen atmosphere, which led to the preparation of carbon-coated nanostructured Ni2P@C(x) catalysts as shown in Fig. 4a, where x represents the initial mass ratio of NaH2PO2 to Ni-MOF-74. The advantage of this method is that it requires only a one-step heat treatment process, which significantly reduces energy consumption and simplifies the preparation process compared to the conventional two-step method. Yang et al. [39] successfully prepared Ru@NC catalyst by pyrolysis of mixture of ruthenium trichloride, urea and carbon carrier through a simple in-situ doping strategy, as shown in Fig. 3 . Urea breaks down and releases nitrogen, which is directly doped into the resulting carbon matrix, where Ru NP is uniformly dispersed on the N-doped carbon material as a high-density bright spot, and Ru, C, and N are uniformly and synchronously distributed across the entire nanostructure. The catalyst has excellent catalytic activity and selectivity for HDO of lignin and furan derivatives under mild conditions. Under the optimal conditions (140 °C, 10 bar H2, 4 h), Ru@NC-800 achieved 100 % vanillin conversion and 94.5 % selectivity for 2‑methoxy-4-methylphenol (MMP). The in-situ doping method often encounters challenges where residual templates (e.g., organic ligands) and stabilizers (e.g., surfactants, polymers) may obstruct or partially encapsulate metal active sites, thereby diminishing catalytic performance through site-blocking effects. Furthermore, despite the promising results exhibited by MOF-derived catalysts in laboratory settings, their application in industrial contexts is hindered by low yields, which stem from complex synthesis conditions, inadequate structural stability of MOFs, and potential structural degradation during catalyst conversion. To address these challenges, it is imperative to optimize synthesis methods to minimize the impact of residuals, develop efficient post-processing techniques to enhance catalyst activity, and improve yields by scaling up laboratory processes, optimizing reaction conditions, and exploring novel MOF materials. These advancements are crucial for the broader industrial application of MOF-derived catalysts. 3.2 Post-processing doping Post-processing doping is a process in which carbon materials are brought into full contact with gases or liquids containing heteroatoms at high temperatures or high pressures to diffuse the heteroatoms into the carbon matrix. This method allows for the preparation of carbon materials that are doped with heteroatoms, thereby altering their electronic structure and chemical properties. The advantage of post-processing doping is that it can be modified for existing carbon materials, and the doping method is relatively flexible. The disadvantage is that it is not possible to achieve a uniform distribution of the heteroatoms throughout the carbon framework, which usually leads only to the doping of the heteroatoms on the surface of the carbon material with poor stability. Ge et al. [40] synthesized the Ni@C material via high-temperature annealing, followed by low-temperature phosphidation to incorporate phosphorus into the material's structure, ultimately forming the Ni2P@C-x catalyst, as shown in Fig. 4b . This catalyst was used for the HDO of lignin-derived vanillin to produce MMP. The Ni2P@C-3 catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic performance under the conditions of 180 °C, 3 h, 0 MPa N2, and isopropanol as the solvent, achieving nearly 100 % conversion of vanillin and a 95 % yield of MMP. The high catalytic activity of this catalyst is primarily attributed to the presence of Niδ+ species, which result from electron transfer from Ni to P, and the P-OH groups in the Ni2P phase that provide additional Lewis acid and Brønsted acid sites. Li et al. [42] synthesized nitrogen-doped carbon nanosheets through the direct pyrolysis of glucosamine hydrochloride (GAH) and melamine. They then loaded highly dispersed and small-sized ruthenium nanoparticles (Ru NPs) onto the nitrogen-doped carbon via the impregnation method. When the weight ratio of melamine to GAH was optimised to 10:1, lignin was successfully converted into aromatic monomers with a yield of up to 40.70 %.Nitrogen-doped carbon-based catalysts with highly dispersed and small-sized ruthenium nanoparticles (Ru NPs) can be synthesized. The following examples of post-processing doping, although applied to supercapacitors, can provide some insight into the synthesis of materials in biomass catalysis. Liu et al. [43] investigated the preparation of 3D honeycomb porous nitrogen-sulfur co-doped carbon (N, S-ACS) from corncob sponge. The corncob sponge was converted into activated carbon (ACS) with a 3D interconnected honeycomb structure by a one-pot method of carbon activation. Subsequently, N,S co-doped ACS was synthesised using thiourea (CH4N2S) as a source of nitrogen and sulfur. The thiourea and the ACS were mixed in deionised water with vigorous stirring, before being dried at 90 °C overnight. The sponge was then subjected to heat treatment under an N2 atmosphere at 800 °C for one hour. The resulting product, a nitrogen-sulfur co-doped activated carbon sponge, was washed with deionised water and dried at 90 °C. Yuan et al. [41] introduced a novel boron and nitrogen co-doped bilayered mesoporous-rich hollow carbon microspheres (B, N-DHCM), as shown in Fig. 4c. The bilayer mesoporous hollow carbon microspheres (DHCM) were initially synthesised using the Stöber method, followed by the introduction of boron and nitrogen elements via a hydrothermal method. This doping process was carried out after the formation of the DHCMs, thus categorising it as post-processing doping. Among the numerous preparation techniques, the post-processing method is particularly popular due to its minimal waste emissions and straightforward operational procedures. By precisely adjusting the quantity of the precursor, the loading of impurity atoms and metals can be effectively controlled. However, when sulfides and phosphides are employed as precursors, phosphide and sulfide ions may persist in the solvent removal process, potentially leading to significant environmental pollution concerns. In addition, to ensure the complete reduction of metal nanoparticles (MNPs), it is usually necessary to use an excessive amount of reducing agent, such as NaBH4 or H2. 4 Single-atom doping Single-atom doping strategies have the potential to significantly enhance the electronic structure and surface chemistry of catalysts, as well as the interactions between metal carriers. The unique properties of different heteroatoms contribute to this improvement, and Table 1 lists the current state of research on single-atom doped (N, S, P, B) carbon-based catalysts, with specific discussions in each section. Carbon-based catalysts doped with heteroatoms have been shown to be effective in facilitating HDO reactions and optimizing product generation, in contrast to undoped catalysts, which tend to exhibit lower conversion and selectivity under the same conditions. 4.1 Nitrogen doped N is adjacent to C in the periodic table and has a similar atomic size to C. It can effectively reduce structural deformation and form stable NC bonds. Nitrogen-doped carbon-based catalysts have made nitrogen the hottest exotic element in heteroatom-doped carbon-based catalysts due to its unique properties, ease of synthesis, and excellent catalytic performance [48]. Appropriate nitrogen doping optimizes the electron distribution of the carbon skeleton, creates more defect sites, and improves the activity and stability of the catalyst by enhancing the metal-carrier interaction [39]. Nitrogen doping can increase the hydrophilicity of carbon materials, which is beneficial for the dispersion of catalysts in the aqueous phase [49]. The introduction of nitrogen atoms changes the acid-base nature of the catalyst, which is a key factor affecting the activity of HDO [50]. Nitrogen-doped catalyst surfaces have higher alkalinity, and this surface alkaline site promotes the dissociation of hydrogen molecules more efficiently to generate active hydrogen species. The increase in active hydrogen species is crucial for the HDO reaction because they can react more efficiently with the oxygen atoms in oxygen-containing compounds to form water or other by-products, thus achieving deoxygenation [51]. Liu et al. [44] reported the HDO reaction of eugenol over CoNx@NC, and the nitrogen-doped carbon carriers showed good performance in stabilizing the Co nanoparticles, Among these catalysts, CoNx@NC-650 demonstrated the highest HDO activity for eugenol conversion, achieving a propylcyclohexanol yield of over 99.9 % after 2 h of reaction under conditions of 2 MPa hydrogen pressure and 200 °C. Chen et al. [45] investigated the catalytic efficiency of nitrogen-doped Pd/NPC-ZIF-8 in the HDO of vanillin within a water/oil biphasic system. The results demonstrated that the nitrogen-doped Pd/NPC-ZIF-8 catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic performance, effectively converting vanillin under conditions of 0.2 MPa hydrogen pressure and 90 °C. In contrast, the vanillin conversion rate using the non-nitrogen-doped Pd/C catalyst was only 36 %, underscoring the critical role of nitrogen doping in enhancing catalytic activity. While Liu et al. [25] explored the effect of nitrogen-doped Pd/C on the HDO of guaiacol, the high-temperature treatment of glucose hydrothermal carbon under nitrogen-doped treatment led to the incorporation of nitrogen atoms into the carbon skeleton, in which the electron-donating ability of pyridine nitrogen and graphitic nitrogen enhanced the electron density of Pd nanoparticles, further boosting the activity of nitrogen-doped Pd/C catalysts and achieving a high benzene yield (85.1 %) and high stability. Zhao et al. [52] prepared an N-doped bimetallic catalyst, RuCoNx/NC, to carry out 4-propylguaiacol HDO cycle experiments. As shown in Fig. 5f , after four cycles, the catalyst still maintained 100 % conversion and the selectivity of the product was close to that of the fresh catalyst. This suggested that the electronic interactions between the metal and the N-doped carbon carriers improved the stability of the catalyst. Similarly, this conclusion was confirmed by the study of Zhu et al. [53], which prepared a nitrogen-doped activated carbon (N-AC) loaded nickel catalyst. The catalytic performance of the catalyst is shown in Fig. 5 g. It was found that nitrogen doping led to an increase in the size of the nickel particles, enhanced the metal-carrier interaction, moved the reduction peak of the nickel oxides towards higher temperatures, and increased the electron density of the nickel atoms. This was conducive to the improvement of the catalytic activity and stability. Sun et al. [54] investigated nitrogen-doped hollow carbon nanorods-anchored palladium nanoparticle catalysts (Pd/HCAFR) for the HDO of acetophenone. It was shown that the amount of nitrogen doping regulated the degree of defects in the hollow carriers and optimized the microenvironment on the catalyst surface, facilitating the dispersion and anchoring of Pd nanoparticles. The hollow carriers promoted the formation of a porous structure, provided more active centres, and facilitated mass transfer flow. Under the synergistic effect of nitrogen doping and hollow carriers, the Pd/HCAFR-0.6 catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic performance for the HDO of acetophenone, achieving an ethylbenzene yield close to 99 %. The catalyst maintained a stable structure and goodcatalytic activity even after five cycles, The preparation and properties of the catalysts are shown in Figs 5a-d. Reina et al. [55] indicated that the effect of nitrogen doping on catalyst performance is primarily in enhancing the deoxygenation ability of the catalyst. Nitrogen doping was found to increase the activity of the N-carrier and N-metal interfaces, which are considered electron-rich regions capable of activating CO bonds. It was confirmed that nitrogen-doped catalysts exhibited higher catalytic activity compared to undoped catalysts. Li et al. [56] found that nitrogen doping helped stabilise and disperse the nickel particles, which were smaller in size (∼6.5 nm on average) and uniformly distributed in Ni/NHPC, whereas the particles in Ni/HPC were larger (∼10.3 nm on average). In the vanillin HDO reaction, the Ni/NHPC catalyst exhibited superior catalytic activity compared to the Ni/HPC catalyst without nitrogen-doped porous carbon. Tan et al. [26] showed that nitrogen doping enhanced the adsorption capacity of the catalyst for reactants and intermediates and led to the formation of a Mott-Schottky heterostructure, which facilitated electron transfer from the alloy core to the carbon shell layer, thus lowering the energy barrier for formic acid dehydrogenation and guaiacol deoxygenation. On the FeCoNi@NC catalyst, due to its higher surface electron density, the conversion of guaiacol reached 93.4 %, and the selectivity for phenol reached 87.3 %, which was superior to that of commercially available Pd/C catalysts. Pastorperez's team investigated the economic feasibility of converting biomass to high-value chemicals using water as a hydrogen source without external hydrogen supply. Nitrogen-doped activated carbon-loaded palladium nanoparticle catalysts [57], nitrogen-doped activated carbon-loaded nickel nanoparticle catalysts [58], and nickel nanoparticles loaded on nitrogen-doped graphene catalysts [55] were prepared for the HDO of guaiacol. It was found that nitrogen-doped catalysts exhibited higher activities compared to non-nitrogen-doped catalysts, especially in the "hydrogen-free" HDO process. Nitrogen doping improves the acid-base and electronic properties of the catalysts, facilitates CO bond breaking and water activation, and enhances the dispersion of metal particles on the catalyst surface. This work provides new perspectives for biomass derivative conversion and H2-free HDO processes without an external hydrogen supply. 4.2 Phosphorous doped Both phosphorus (P) and nitrogen (N) have three valence electrons, but phosphorus atoms have a stronger electron-donating ability due to their larger size and less electronegativity, a property that has led to phosphorus-doped carbon-based catalysts showing excellent performance [59]. It has been shown that the 3p orbitals of phosphorus can effectively interact with the 2p orbitals of carbon, thus facilitating the transition of sp2 hybridized carbon to the sp3 hybridized state [60]. During this process, a phosphorus atom often tends to form a pyramid-like bonding structure with three carbon atoms [61]. In addition, the addition of phosphorus induces a structural distortion of the carbon network, making the entire carbon-based network structurally looser due to its larger atomic radius [62]. Wang et al. [63] demonstrated that phosphorus incorporation decreased the reducing and H2 adsorption capacity and enhanced the acidity of the catalyst, especially the number of weakly acidic sites. Zhu et al. [64] found that Ni2P catalysts were significantly more effective than Ni catalysts in promoting HDO reactions for biomass-derived phenolic compounds, with a conversion rate of 96.3 % for m-cresol, compared to just 14.1 % for Ni catalysts. Similarly, Ge et al. [40] compared the catalytic performance of Ni@C and Ni2P@C-x in the HDO of lignin-derived vanillin. The results indicated that the Ni2P@C-x ("x" refers to the molar ratio of the phosphorus source to the nickel source) catalysts significantly enhanced the reaction activity, with the Ni2P@C-3 catalyst achieving nearly 100 % vanillin conversion and a 95 % yield of the target product, MMP, under the reaction conditions of 180 °C and 3 h. This improvement can be attributed to P doping, which not only facilitated the formation of the active Ni2P phase but also increased the number of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites on the catalyst surface, thereby improving the adsorption and activation of the reactants. Additionally, the presence of P-OH groups significantly enhanced the surface acidity of the catalyst, further boosting its catalytic performance. Wang et al. [18] prepared a carbon-coated Ni2P catalyst (Ni2P@C) for phenol HDO reaction. The phosphorus-doped catalyst showed significantly higher deoxygenation activity compared with the conventional Ni@C catalyst, which was attributed to the fact that phosphorus species promoted the cyclohexanol dehydration reaction to produce cyclohexane. The complete conversion of phenol was achieved at 250 °C, 2 MPa H2 and 2 h. The total yield of deoxygenated products reached 100 %. CorderoLanzac et al. [65] prepared Pt-Pd/ACP catalyst by loading Pt-Pd on phosphorus-containing activated carbon (ACP). It was found that the C5+ hydrocarbon and liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) yields of the Pt-Pd/ACP catalyst were 20.5 and 9.6 wt%, respectively, and the yields of the Pt-Pd/FCC (for fluidized catalytic cracking) catalyst were lower (13.9 and 4.5 wt%, respectively) under the reaction conditions of 450 °C, indicating that the activity of the Pt-Pd/ACP catalyst was significantly higher than that of the Pt-Pd/FCC catalyst, which was mainly attributed to the abundance of acidic sites on the ACP carriers, which were formed by the P component on the carbon surface. Gao et al. [66] synthesized a series of phosphorus-doped PV-carbon based catalysts, and the catalyst characterization is shown in Fig. 6 . Phosphorus doping not only introduces the lattice defects efficiently, but also promotes the delocalization of electrons remarkably, which can transform the carbon material into a metal-like energy band structure. This transformation greatly enhances the effective activation of hydrogen molecules and nitro groups, providing a kinetic advantage for the hydrogenation of nitroaromatics. DFT calculations confirmed that phosphorus doping can promote hydrogen desorption and enhance the catalyst activity. Hita et al. [67] intensively investigated Pt-Pd and Ni-W catalysts loaded on ACP for the hydrogen deoxygenation of bio-oils and quality enhancement. It was found that doping by P provided acidic sites for the carbon carriers, which promoted highly selective generation of aromatics and improved the stability of the catalysts. Zheng et al. [68] prepared Ni-P-C catalysts for the hydrogenation of chlorodifluoromethane (HCFC-22), and it was found that 5 % Ni-P-C exhibited better catalytic performance compared to 5 % Ni/C, which was attributed to the fact that the doped P was able to promote the dispersion of Ni species on the P-C surface through strong interactions with the Ni and P-C carriers. 4.3 Boron doped Boron atoms are similar in size to carbon atoms, and boron doping does not cause significant structural changes in carbon materials, maintaining their unique properties [69]. Boron atoms have electron-deficient properties, which can alter the electronic structure of carbon materials, rendering them p-type semiconductors [70]. Boron doping can also enhance the stability of carbon materials, allowing them to perform well in high-temperature environments. However, it should be noted that boron doping may introduce defects and impurities, potentially affecting the performance of carbon materials [71]. Researchers have found that moderate boron doping can enhance the activity of the catalyst, whereas excessive boron doping results in decreased activity. Additionally, boron doping can improve the resistance of the catalyst to carbon buildup, thereby extending its lifetime. Therefore, when performing boron doping, the doping concentration and method must be strictly controlled to achieve optimal performance. Luo et al. [72] employed H3BO3 coupled with Ru/C for the HDO of lignin oils and phenolic compounds. H3BO3 was employed as a homogeneous catalyst in combination with Ru/C catalysts to overcome product segregation, exhibiting superior catalytic performance over liquid organic and inorganic acids, with good recoverability. Treating lignocellulosic oil with this catalyst increased the hydrocarbon content from 7.9 % to 93.1 %, enhancing the feasibility of using upgraded lignocellulosic oil directly as a fuel. Wei et al. [73] synthesized various amounts of boron-modified Ni/Mo2C catalysts and investigated the catalytic effect of boron on Ni/Mo2C catalysts in the alkaline lignocellulosic HDO process, as shown in Fig. 7 . xB-Ni/Mo2C (x = 0.5, 1, 3, 5) catalysts increased lignin conversion and bio-oil yield, with the "x" representing the percentage by weight (wt%) of different amounts of boron added to the Ni/Mo2C catalyst. Under the reaction conditions of 2 MPa, 290 °C and 2 h, the bio-oil yield of 1B-Ni/Mo2C catalyst is the highest, which is 63.8 %. This may be attributed to the strong interactions between boron and nickel species, which increased the catalyst's specific surface area and the dispersion of nickel particles. The increase in acidic centres promoted the breaking of CO and CC bonds, thereby enhancing the activity of the catalyst. Ai et al. [74] investigated boron-doped layered porous carbon (B-LPC) as a catalyst carrier for the hydrogenation of dimethyl oxalate (DMO). It was found that the ethylene glycol selectivity of the Cu/B-LPC catalyst at 240 °C was as high as 94.1 %, significantly higher than the 77.0 % of the undoped Cu/LPC catalyst. This was attributed to boron doping strengthening the interaction between Cu species and B-LPC, which not only stabilised the Cu nanoparticles but also regulated the valence of Cu species to maintain more active Cu sites. 4.4 Sulfur doped S doping involves an adsorption-bonding process where S atoms are initially adsorbed onto the lattice as S and C atoms approach each other, followed by a bonding or substitution reaction between the S and C atoms [75]. The incorporation of S atoms into the carbon lattice induces strain and stress, altering the charge distribution and occasionally promoting oxygen chemisorption [76]. Introducing elemental sulfur into carbon materials effectively modulates the electronic structure and surface properties of catalysts, thereby enhancing their catalytic activity in HDO reactions [77]. Kim et al. [47] investigated the positive effect of sulfur doping on the Ru/AC catalyst in a low-temperature HDO reaction, achieving 100 % guaiacol conversion. It was found that sulfur doping influenced the dispersion state, accessibility, and electronic properties of Ru, enhancing the adsorption and activation of H2 molecules and facilitating the generation of cyclohexane, the complete deoxygenation product. Zhang et al. [78] prepared sulfur-doped carbon-loaded palladium catalysts Pd/CS for the hydrogenation of chloronitrobenzene (o-CNB) using Na2S- 9H2O as a sulfur source, exhibiting 100 % conversion and over 99.9 % selectivity to o-chloroaniline (o-CAN). It was shown that with the decrease of sulfur valence state, the electronic effect between sulfur and palladium was enhanced, leading to the decrease of palladium's adsorption and dissociation of hydrogen, which led to the improvement of selectivity and the reduction of the formation of excessive hydrogenation by-products. Additionally, Liu et al. [79] used metal-sulfur coordination chemistry to successfully prepare Pd1-S-C catalysts, the intrinsic active site of the Pd1-S-C catalysts features a unique tetrahedral PdS4 structure. Compared to the electron-deficient PdN4 site, the PdS4 site exhibits an upward shift of the d-band centre, enhancing the dissociative activation of H2 molecules. The electron-rich PdS4 unit site promotes the activation of H2 molecules and the desorption of CC intermediates more effectively than the electron-poor PdN4 unit site, as shown in Fig. 8 . Chen et al. [80] demonstrated that sulfur atoms, as strong coordination sites, can form M-S interfaces between metal nanoparticles and sulfur-doped carbon-based materials, such as the Ir-S interface formed between Iridium (Ir) nanoparticles and sulfur. This interface significantly affects the electron transfer process at the interface by changing the electronic structure of the metal. The study shows that the activity of the catalyst is proportional to the number of M-S interfaces, indicating that these interfaces play a crucial role in the catalytic process, especially in improving the activity and stability of metal nanocatellites. Li et al. [81] utilized the strong interactions between the metal and the sulfur-doped carbon carriers to prepare a Ru M with mesoporous sulfur-doped carbon (meso_SC) support (M = Ga, In, Ge, Sn, Ni) bimetallic nanocluster catalyst. The interaction between metal and sulfur atoms significantly inhibits the aggregation of metal species during hydrogen reduction at 600 °C, thereby ensuring the formation of small-sized alloyed nanoclusters. However, sulfur-doped catalysts suffer from sulfur loss during the reaction process, leading to catalyst deactivation and product contamination, commonly referred to as sulfur poisoning. Careful consideration of their stability and potential sulfur loss needs to be addressed in practical applications. 5 Atomic co-doping Co-doping typically involves the simultaneous doping of N with another heteroatom (e.g., B, O, S, P) into a carbon material [82]. In contrast to single-atom doped carbon-based catalysts, atomic co-doping further modulates the state of the metal atoms [83]. N doping increases the electrical conductivity and modulates the electronic structure, B doping alters the electronic structure of the carbon material inducing carbon surface defects that serve as reactive defect sites, and S, P, and O doping widens the spacing of the carbon layers, enhances the charge density and asymmetric spins of the carbon-based material, and activates carbon's chemical activity. It can be seen that the rational design of heteroatom-doped carbon-based catalysts plays an important role for HDO of biomass derivatives. Table 2 summarizes the current status of research and development of atomically co-doped carbon-based catalysts. However, due to its complexity, co-doping is less studied compared to single-atom doping in the field of HDO of biomass derivatives, necessitating further research. 5.1 Nitrogen-boron co-doped On the atomic scale, B, N, and C atoms are similar in size, which helps maintain the lattice integrity of carbon materials and reduces structural distortion [88]. More importantly, since boron atoms exhibit electron-deficient properties while nitrogen atoms are electron-rich, co-doping boron and nitrogen in a carbon matrix can lead to electron redistribution. This affects the electronic structure of the carbon material, consequently altering its chemical and catalytic properties [89]. Zhao et al. [90] pointed out that N doping enhances the reactivity and conductivity of the material by introducing defects due to the higher electronegativity of N atoms compared to C atoms. Meanwhile, when N doping is combined with B doping, the difference in electronegativity between B, N, and C leads to the formation of dipole moments in the material skeleton. This inhomogeneous charge distribution facilitates the absorption of CO2 with quadrupole polarity through dipole-dipole interactions. This observation was also confirmed by Yuan et al. [41], who used ammonium tetraborate tetrahydrate (NH4B5O8·4H2O) as the boron and nitrogen source. Hollow carbon microspheres enriched with mesopores (B, N-DHCM) were prepared by a hydrothermal method. It was found that co-doping N with B creates a compensatory effect with the electron-deficient structure of B and the electron-rich structure of N, generating more active sites than single-atom doping, compared to undoped DHCM. Li et al. [91] constructed metal-free catalysts by N and B co-doping strategy, and the presence of B-N bonds may lead to charge neutralization effect between electron donor (N) and electron acceptor (B) in the doped carbon materials, which attenuates the electronic effect produced by the heteroatoms in the materials. This neutralization effect may limit the formation of diverse active sites, which in turn weakens the overall activity of the catalyst. Therefore, although B-N co-doping can improve the stability of the material in some cases, it may also hinder the efficient construction of highly active sites, which may adversely affect the catalytic performance. Ozaki et al. [92] suggested that nitrogen and boron co-doping can enhance the activity of metal catalysts due to the synergistic interactions between nitrogen and boron atoms, which produce higher adsorption energies, leading to an increased density of active sites. Qiu et al. [93] investigated the mechanism of pore space enhancement and ion adsorption by co-doping with B and N by comparing the energy of adsorption (Eads) of different models through DFT calculations. The B and N-doped carbon carriers have higher adsorption energies than pure graphite, indicating that B and N doping favours ion adsorption in carbon materials. This may be because the pore and doping energies disrupt the original charge balance of carbon, leading to significant charge transfer and redistribution, generating additional electrochemically active sites, and thus enhancing ion adsorption performance.Yao et al. [94] proposed a chained B and N co-doping method in which the B-N bonds and N-6/N-5 groups promote each other, resulting in the incorporation of more B and N atoms into the carbon skeleton. This significantly improves the electrical conductivity (1225 S m −1) and specific surface area (880 m2 g −1) of porous carbon nanosheets (PCNs). It was found that the positive charge of the B atoms helped neutralize the negative charge of the carbon skeleton and promoted the formation of B-N bonds, suggesting that B and N co-doping has a synergistic enhancement effect on ion adsorption. Zhang et al. [95] reported a one-pot method for the synthesis of boron and nitrogen co-doped nanocarbon (BNC) catalysts for efficiently catalyzing the reduction reaction of nitrophenol, as shown in Fig. 9 . In the reduction reaction of 4-nitrophenol, the synthesized BNCH-0.30 catalyst showed high catalytic activity with a low activation energy of 30.65 kJ mol−1. Additionally, the BNCH-0.30 catalyst exhibited good stability and reusability over seven cycles. Hu et al. [96] used ZnCl₂-assisted pyrolysis of covalent organic frameworks (COFs) to prepare N,B co-doped carbon-based catalysts for the nitroaromatics hydrogenation reaction. It was found that ZnCl₂ helped maintain the microporous structure of COFs, providing high specific surface area and defects. The presence of B heteroatoms promoted an increase in the proportion of pyrrole nitrogen at the defects. By modulating the surface area and reactive nitrogen species, 99.9 % nitrobenzene conversion and >99 % aniline selectivity were achieved. The catalysts also exhibited good substrate suitability and stability. 5.2 Nitrogen-Sulfur co-doped Nitrogen and sulfur co-doped carbon-based catalysts are characterised by their unique microporous structure, high specific surface area, and increased active sites and defects [97]. N and S co-doping results in the formation of abundant acidic sites and oxygen vacancies on the surface of the catalysts. These properties effectively reduce the energy barriers to chemical reactions and promote the adsorption and activation of reactants [98]. Additionally, N and S co-doping can precisely regulate the number of active sites in carbon-based catalysts. This synergistic effect between the elements plays a crucial role in enhancing the overall catalytic performance of the catalysts [99]. Kuang et al. [27] synthesized a series of N, S-doped carbon spheres supported Pd catalysts (Pd/CNS(X), X represents the ratio of S,N precursors), using 3-aminophenol as the carbon and nitrogen source and trithiocyanuric acid as the sulfur source. Among these, the Pd/CNS(1) catalyst showed a vanillin conversion of >99.8 % and MMP selectivity close to 100 % in the HDO reaction at 50 °C for 3 h. Compared with the single-atom doped catalysts, Pd/CNS(1) showed higher activity and selectivity. N and S co-doping led to the formation of abundant defects on the surface of the carbon carriers, enhancing the stability of the Pd nanoparticles and facilitating the transfer of electrons from the carriers to the Pd. This enhanced the interaction between the metal and the carriers. Lang et al. [84] investigated novel N and S co-doped carbon-based catalysts NSCC-T-X for the preparation of MMP by HDO of vanillin, where X denotes the mass ratio of melamine to 2-benzimidazolethiol and T refers to the temperature. It was found that NSCC-800–7 exhibited the best catalytic performance at 240 °C, 1 MPa H2, 4 h, with vanillin conversion and MMP selectivity reaching 81.32 % and 77.30 %, respectively. This was mainly attributed to the high specific surface area of the catalyst, abundant N and S co-doping, and the active sites of NSVs. Duan et al. [100] disclosed for the first time an efficient and stable nitrogen-sulfur co-doped carbon-based catalyst with FeS2 nanoparticles loaded on gradient carbon as a carrier (referred to as FeS2/NSC). This catalyst was successfully applied in the nitro olefin hydrotreating reaction for the production of aniline, and the preparation and characterization of the catalyst are shown in Fig. 10 . XRD and TEM (Fig. 10c, d, and F) showed that single-phase FeS2 nanoparticles were highly uniformly dispersed on the carrier surface in the prepared FeS2/NSC catalysts, exhibiting a hierarchical porous structure and excellent porosity. This achieved a uniform distribution of active sites over the entire catalyst surface. XPS analysis (Fig. 10e) revealed the chemical state of Fe-Nx, suggesting significant interactions between FeS2 nanoparticles and nitrogen atoms in the carbon framework. Hou et al. [101] showed that carbon-based nanocatalysts composed of atomically dispersed sulfur- and nitrogen-doped nickel nitrides embedded in carbon nanosheets significantly enhanced the charge density of carbon-based materials and induced asymmetry in the spin states, improving the accessibility of the active sites compared to conventional metal- or heteroatom-doped carbon-based catalysts. The size effect of sulfur atoms can result in local distortions of the carbon matrix, thereby introducing additional active sites and defects. The increase in these defects and active sites results in electronegativity differences between the S- and N-atoms, which facilitates the rapid transfer of H+. The co-doping of sulfur and nitrogen controls the size and morphology of the metal particles by modifying the electronic structure and surface properties of the carbon matrix, which may influence the nucleation and growth processes. Furthermore, localized distortions may also alter the exposure plane of the metal particles, which subsequently affects their catalytic activity. Lu et al. [102] developed nitrogen-sulfur co-doped carbon quantum dots (N, S-CQDs)-modified palladium (Pd) nanoparticle catalysts for the hydrogenation reaction. N, S co-doping significantly enhanced the activity and selectivity of the Pd catalyst, promoted the adsorption and dissociation of hydrogen through the formation of a Pd-S interface, and simultaneously enhanced electron transfer from Pd to S. This effectively inhibited undesired hydrohalogenation reactions, resulting in Pd@N, S-CQDs catalysts exhibiting 100 % conversion and selectivity in various halogenated nitrobenzene hydrogenation reactions. The stabilizing effect of N, S doping on palladium nanoparticles and the electron transfer phenomenon confirmed the enhancement of catalyst performance by N, S co-doping. Hu et al. [103] applied nitrogen-sulfur co-doping to palladium-loaded graphene-like carbon materials. Experimental results showed that N, S co-doping significantly enhanced the electronic structure and hydrotreating activity of the Pd catalysts. This led to N/O/S co-doped Pd@GS1000 catalysts exhibiting 100 % conversion and selectivity for the quinoline hydrotreating reaction under mild conditions, superior to the un-sulfur doped control catalyst. 5.3 Nitrogen-Phosphorus co-doped Nitrogen and phosphorus co-doped carbon-based catalysts have demonstrated excellent catalytic properties in the HDO of biomass derivatives. Compared with N atoms, P atoms have a larger atomic radius, and the length of the C-P bond formed (0.177 nm) is significantly longer than that of the CN bond (0.141 nm) [104]. In terms of electronegativity, N (3.04) is more electronegative than C (2.55), while P (2.19) is less electronegative than C. Therefore, the polarity of the C-P bond is opposite to that of the CN bond, which implies that phosphorus doping can create more defect sites and new active sites different from those created by nitrogen doping [105]. Hu et al. [85] investigated N and P co-doped carbon-encapsulated nickel catalysts (Ni@NP-C) for the aqueous-phase hydrogenation rearrangement tandem reaction (AP-HRT) of biomass-derived furan FAL to produce cyclopentanone (CPO), the catalyst preparation and properties are shown in Fig 11 . They achieved 100 % furfural conversion and 86.7 % CPO yield at 130 °C, 1.5 MPa H2, and 2 h. This success was attributed to the introduction of heteroatoms that increased the surface polarity of the catalyst, enhanced the chemisorption of reactants, and formed weak Lewis acid sites on the catalyst surface. These weak Lewis acid sites interacted with the carbonyl C = O and CO bonds in FAL, promoting the hydrogenation rearrangement reaction and the conversion of reactants to CPO, thus improving the selectivity and yield of CPO. Chen et al. [106] prepared an N, P co-doped carbon-coated catalyst (Co@NPC) for the aqueous-phase hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde. Co@NPC achieved 92.1 % conversion of cinnamaldehyde and 79.7 % selectivity to cinnamyl alcohol under the reaction conditions of 80 °C, 0.5 MPa hydrogen pressure, and 5 h. Compared with the undoped catalyst Co@C, N and P doping significantly improved the catalytic performance. P doping improved the selectivity of cinnamyl alcohol, while N doping was closely related to the catalytic activity of the catalyst. The activity and selectivity of the reaction could be controlled by adjusting the amount of doping. DFT results showed that the differences in electronegativity between N, P, and C atoms led to electron interactions, changing the catalyst's Co and CoO ratio, which enhanced the adsorption strength of cinnamaldehyde on the catalyst surface, thereby regulating the reaction products based on the difference in adsorption energy. Duan et al. [107] loaded cobalt nanoparticles onto N and P co-doped carbon shells (Co@NPC) for the hydrogenation of nitroaromatics. The carbon doped with P and N exhibited synergistic effects with the encapsulated Co nanoparticles, showing unique selectivity and excellent activity towards aniline. Yang et al. [108] synthesized a layered porous carbon sphere catalyst (NPS-HPCs) containing sulfur, phosphorus, and nitrogen co-doping with a layered porous structure of micro-, meso‑, and macropores, with a specific surface area of up to 960 m²/g. This catalyst exhibited excellent performance in the hydrogenation of nitroaromatics with a high turnover frequency (TOF) value of about 953 h −1. Geng et al. [109] prepared N, P, S co-doped MoC catalysts using proton ionic liquids as precursors, which exhibited excellent catalytic activity during hydrogenation, due to the N, P and S doping in the carbon skeleton which enhanced the electron transfer between MoIV+ and Mo&+ species and promoted the adsorption and activation of CO2 and H2. Shao et al. [110] reported a Pd-loaded N, P co-doped carbon-based catalyst (Pd/NPC) exhibiting excellent catalytic performance in bicarbonate hydrogenation. DFT results showed that N and P co-doping synergistically modulated the electronic properties of the carbon carriers. Xiong et al. [111] synthesized N, P co-doped activated carbon-loaded nickel catalysts (Ni/NP-ACs) for the hydrogenation of 1,5-dinitronaphthalene. Ni/NP-ACs-900 exhibited good catalytic activity comparable to that of commercial Pd/C catalysts, with a 1,5-diaminonaphthalene yield of up to 95.8 %. DFT calculations showed that the defects formed by N and P doping strengthened the interactions between the nickel nanoparticles and carbon carriers, facilitating the homogeneous distribution and anchoring of nickel. This promoted the dissociation and adsorption of H2. Wei et al. [112] proposed that N, P co-doped carbon-based catalysts (PNC) possess anti-SOx, NOx, and POx poisoning properties. This is attributed to the electronic structure modulation induced by nitrogen-phosphorus co-doping, where phosphorus doping optimizes the charge and spin density of the catalysts through its 3p lone pair of electrons to promote oxygen adsorption, while nitrogen doping enhances the electron density and the edge active sites of the catalyst. 5.4 Nitrogen-Oxygen co-doped Nitrogen and oxygen co-doped carbon-based catalysts are novel catalytic materials that effectively extend the application scope of carbon materials in the field of catalysis, especially in processes such as HDO of biomass and capacitive deionization (CDI) [113,114], which exhibit excellent catalytic activity and stability. Yu et al. [86] used resin polymer microspheres as precursors and prepared N and O co-doped Pd@APF-H2O2 catalysts using in situ pyrolysis and H2O2 post-treatment processes as shown in Fig. 12 for vanillin HDO studies. The vanillin conversion was 100 % and MMP selectivity was 99.2 % at 120 °C and 4 MPa H2. Based on the above study, Yu et al. [87] proposed another M@NC-H2O2 (M = Co, Ni) catalyst, in which Co@NC-H2O2 was prepared with a three-dimensional hierarchical porous nanostructure, abundant continuously crosslinked meso‑ and macropores, and the metal Co NPs with an average particle size of about 20 nm were encapsulated in an apparent carbon layer, which acted as an outer shell to prevent the Co nuclei from being corroded and aggregated under the HDO reaction.The catalyst showed good catalytic activity and stability for vanillin HDO, and the conversion of vanillin reached 100 % and the selectivity of 2‑methoxy-4-methylphenol reached 99.4 % under the conditions of 150 °C, 4 MPa H2, and 4 h, respectively. Dinh et al. [115] prepared N,O co-doped porous oxidized biochar (O,N-doped OBC) by air oxidation. This approach not only provided a natural source of O and N doping but also improved the porous structure of O,N-doped OBC. Meng et al. [116] found that N and O co-doping could enhance the performance of CDI by triggering a significant pseudocapacitance contribution, which was attributed to the fact that N and O co-doping led to the generation of abundant active sites on the surface of carbon materials, as well as optimizing the pore structure, which was conducive to the formation of the electric double layer. 6 Conclusions and outlook Heteroatom-doped carbon-based catalysts exhibit significant advantages in the HDO of biomass derivatives. Carbon materials are widely used as catalyst carriers for HDO reactions due to their excellent electronic conductivity, high specific surface area and tunable surface functional groups. The introduction of heteroatoms such as N, P, B, and S has become one of the effective ways to modify the properties of carbon materials. Doping strategies can be categorized into in situ synthesis and post-processing, where the former directly introduces heteroatoms into the carbon skeleton and the latter dopes and modifies existing carbon materials. Heteroatom doping can further enhance the hydrophilicity of the carbon material for better dispersion of the catalyst in the aqueous medium, and enhance the dispersion of the metal active phase by adjusting the acid-base property and charge distribution of the carbon material to improve the catalyst activity. In addition, the heteroatom synergistic effect not only enhances the reaction efficiency of the catalyst, but also optimizes its stability and reduces the side reactions in the catalytic process. Although heteroatom-doped carbon-based catalysts exhibit excellent performance in biomass HDO reactions, they still face many challenges in practical applications. On the one hand, the complexity and non-homogeneity of biomass derivatives make the efficient conversion difficult. Future studies should pay more attention to the design of catalysts, especially in improving the catalyst selectivity and controlling the reaction pathways, and explore the relationship between heteroatom doping modification and the catalytic mechanism through more comprehensive and profound characterization and computational studies, in order to achieve a more efficient HDO effect. On the other hand, the development of low-cost, wide range of feedstocks and simple and novel preparation methods will greatly facilitate the transition from laboratory to industrial production applications. In addition, the recovery and reusability of catalysts are also the focus of future research. coredata.dc:description: Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of biomass derivatives is a critical method for converting these resources into fuels and chemicals. Carbon-based catalysts play a crucial role in HDO. In this review, the main advances and problems of heteroatom-doped carbon-based catalysts for the HDO of biomass derivatives, both domestically and internationally, in recent years are summarized. Herein, the review first summarizes the reaction mechanisms of HDO of typical model compounds. From the perspective of preparation methods of carbon-based catalysts, the advantages and shortcomings of in-situ doping and post-processing doping strategies are compared. The current research status of carbon-based catalysts is reviewed in terms of single-atom doping (N, P, B, and S) and atom co-doping (N-B, N-S, N-P, and NO), highlighting that heteroatom doping can introduce more acid-base sites on carbon-based materials, enhance their hydrophilicity, chemical stability, and conductivity. Additionally, anchor sites for metal nanoparticles can be provided to enhance their dispersion and stability, altering the electron distribution and charge density of the carbon-based catalysts, thus significantly improving catalytic efficiency and product selectivity. Finally, the review addresses current challenges and future research directions, emphasizing the need for rational catalyst design and a deeper understanding of the reaction mechanism to enhance biomass resource utilization.
